node.title: MOOSE setting all my material properties to zero?
node.bodyText:
In my material file, I declare the property using:
_len_scale(declareADProperty("length_scale")),
and after computing it in computeQpProperties, I added a print statement there- its outputting exactly what it's supposed to. Then in the kernel, I "get" this value with:
_len_scale(getADMaterialPropertyByName("length_scale")),
printing this outputs 0.000000. The same for all other material properties. I find this strange because its worked in the past. If I understand correctly, the string in quotes declared in the material file is what is being retrieved when I use "getADMaterialPropertyByName", right? The only different thing I could think of is that this is the first time I'm running a transient solve.
The material property is a constant, btw. That is, what I computed in computeQpProperties depends only on values given from the user in the input file, so it's not supposed to change or be affected by anything else.
I checked other materials, and they are all 0.000000 as well. I only caught this after I got an arithmetic exception somewhere else because of a division operation.

Hello
Is _len_scale declared like this in the header?
const ADMaterialProperty & _len_scale ;
If len_scale is not declared as a reference, that would be the problem. But there's a guard (non-reference routine is private in MaterialProperty.h) against assigning it to a value so I doubt it's that.
Guillaume

Hi,
Yes it's declared like this:
const ADMaterialProperty & _len_scale;
with a (Real) after ADMaterialProperty in angled brackets
for both the material and the kernel right
Yes for both
But in the material, it's not const though, since I have to assign _len_scale[_qp] in computeQpProperties

@rwcarlsen on mat props.
not sure what is going on here

Could you show more snippets of the code where you declare the property in the material, compute/assign the property,  retrieve the property in another object, and use the property in another object?  Are you using any non-default execute_on parameters for any objects, etc.?  Just need more context to help you diagnose.

Is the property declared as an AD property to begin with?  AD and non-AD properties are tracked separately.  So you need to declare+retrieve them consistently as AD and non-AD.  Also - just to confirm - the declaration for the member var is const ADMaterialProperty<Real> & _len_scale; - right?  Also just want to confirm - are your printfs in your kernel for the property values inside the computeQpResidual function?  Because inside the constructor or other functions, the properties will not be computed/ready.
And _len_scale[_qp] = some calc is being done in computeValue of the material right?

Yes, the values from the user are initialized with ADReal, and then getParam<Real> to retrieve them. They're then calculated in computeQpProperties() (@GiudGiud, not computeValue(), is that the function I should be overriding?), and assigned to variables declared like const ADMaterialProperty<Real> & _len_scale; . Then, in each of the kernels, they are retrieved with _len_scale(getADMaterialPropertyByName("length_scale")),
And yes I added the print statement inside computeQpResidual(). I also added print statements to the other kernels, but the solver isn't getting to them yet.

Could you show the code in your header and .C files where you define your material property member variable and retrieve it?  Sometimes people have silly mistakes like retrieving the material property and storing it into a material property value instead of a reference member variable.
[edit] - never mind - looks like you declared the member var right. Hmmm...

node.title: Peacock issues with Bigsur
node.bodyText:
Hello
I am new to moose and I am running it on Mac OS Bigsur 11.5. I have read that there were some issues including failing moose tests and segmentation fault while running peacock. I have been trying to find a solution yet I am not sure if all these issues were resolved or still under development.
thank you

BigSur will by default install a version of XCode that does not work (see discussion #17722 for details).
If the above is not applicative to you, can you copy/paste the error(s) you are receiving along with the command that invoked them? Please refrain from pasting screen shots where possible.

Hi
Thank you for your response. I have resolved the peacock issue and it is working fine where I applied the following fix after reinstalling moose, instead of installing moose-libmesh and moos-tools through
conda install moose-tools
conda install moose-libmesh
I installed it by typing the following in terminal
conda deactivate
conda install mamba
mamba create -n moose moose-libmesh moose-tools
conda activate moose
This have solved my issue which I believe was python version related. However as for the failing moose tests I am still having a large number of tests failing. The test I ran was
cd ~/projects/moose/test
make -j 4
./run_tests -j 4
and that resulted to the following:

Thank you! Looks like you are running into the common mpich gethostbyname failure.
We have a section dedicated to this error on our FAQ. The exact link is: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/help/troubleshooting.html#failingtests
Here is an except of those FAQs that pertains to this issue (I modified it just a touch to be easier to read):


gethostbyname failed, localhost (errno 3)
This is a fairly common occurrence which happens when your internal network stack / route, is not correctly configured for the local loopback device. Thankfully, there is an easy fix:


Obtain your hostname:
$> hostname
mycoolname


Linux & Macintosh : Add the results of hostname to your /etc/hosts file. Like so:
$> sudo vi /etc/hosts

127.0.0.1  localhost

# The following lines are desirable for IPv6 capable hosts
::1        localhost ip6-localhost ip6-loopback
ff02::1    ip6-allnodes
ff02::2    ip6-allrouters

127.0.0.1  mycoolname  # <--- add this line to the end of your hosts file
Everyone's host file is different. But the results of adding the necessary line described above will be the same.


Macintosh only, 2nd method:
$> sudo scutil --set HostName mycoolname
We have received reports where the second method sometimes does not work.
Thank you very much the first method worked !

Hi,
I am having a problem with compiling my code. Last night it was working great and I was getting great results. i havent changed anything since last night. Earlier this morning, I "make clean" and tried to compile and it keeps telling me
There appears to be a libMesh update in progress for
the branch of MOOSE you are operating on (only the
master branch contains publicly available moose-libmesh
packages).
You must provide your own libMesh either by:
1. Uninstall moose-libmesh and build it manually via
   moose/scripts/update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh

or
2. Use conda build to build your own moose-libmesh
package.
/home/ahmad68/projects/moose/framework/moose.mk:15: *** Build failed.  Stop.
I updated the libmesh by building my own libmesh, and still same error. Could you please help me with that?
Thanks

Note: I asked my groupmates, they have never faced this issue before. It doesn't make sense to me yet why I would have to update my library.
I updated it using this website https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/help/faq/faq_build_libmesh.html
but it still not working. I also updated Conda, still not working too and it gives me same messege.

Hello
Can you please first try to clean the build from the repository?
First, just try make clobberall. If that is not enough, commit ALL your changes, then run git clean -xfd (will remove everything that is not committed).
Then we have just updated libmesh and petsc a week ago, so it s worth updating your moose and libmesh.
So
git fetch origin; git pull origin to get the latest moose
conda update --all to update libmesh.
Best,
Guillaume

but I am getting Segmentation fault messege.

What platform? What operating system?
Try conda clean -a see if it removes the segfault. Some python packages you could have pip-installed can cause seg faults for conda, but it s rare

I'll add a little bit to the posting guidelines to reflect this

node.title: Orthotropic Thermal conductivity
node.bodyText: Hi folks, I've come across a problem where I'd like to have different themal conductivities in the x,y,z directions as a function of temperature. Is this currently possible?

AnisoHeatConduction allows you to define (k_xx, k_yy, k_zz), but not an arbitrary tensor.
Not in PorousFlow, sorry.  We have anisotropic thermal conductivity that is a function of saturation.  You'd have to implement it yourself if you want to use PorousFlow.

Just replace the HeatConduction kernel with AnisotropicDiffusion. You need to define your tensor valued conduction coefficient.
If your orthotropic diffusivity is inhomogeneous, you need to use MatAnisoDiffusion and define your tensor valued conduction coefficient as a material property.

Thats great, AnisoHeatConduction is exactly, what I wanted. Now, just to be awkward, I would like the k_xx, k_yy and k_zz to be functions. I did something like (where tcx etc are regular peicewiselinear functions.
  [cfc_tile]
    type = AnisoHeatConductionMaterial
    block = 'bdcu-tile'
    specific_heat_temperature_function = cp_dms704
    thermal_conductivity_x = tcx
    thermal_conductivity_y = tcy
    thermal_conductivity_z = tcz
    temp = temp
  []

It doesnt seem to like that, so instead I'm going the pp route
  [cfc_tile]
    type = AnisoHeatConductionMaterial
    block = 'bdcu-tile'
    specific_heat_temperature_function = cp_dms704
    thermal_conductivity_x_pp = tcx
    thermal_conductivity_y_pp = tcy
    thermal_conductivity_z_pp = tcz
    temp = temp
  []
[]

What isnt clear to me is in the postprocessor section
[Postprocessors]
  [./tcx]
    type = FunctionValuePostprocessor
    function = my_function
    outputs = none
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  [../]

What isn't clear to me, is how I pass the temperature to this function? Should I use something like
[Functions]
  [tc_z_dms704]
    type = PiecewiseLinear
    x = '313.15 393.15 493.15 593.15 693.15 793.15 893.15
         993.15 1093.15 1193.15 1293.15 1393.15 1493.15
         1593.15 1693.15'
    y = '67.21 62.12 56.38 51.25 46.66 42.57 38.91 35.64
         32.72 30.11 27.78 25.7 23.84 22.17 20.69'
  []
[]
[Postprocessors]
  [./tcx]
    type = FunctionValuePostprocessor
    function = tc_dms704
    indirect_dependencies = get_temp
    outputs = none
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  [../]
  [get_temp]
    type = ScalarVariable
    variable = temp
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  [../]
[]

I.e. how on earth do I let the postprocessor know that I want to pass the temperature into the function as the argument f(temperature)?
Why do you take a harder route?
Is there an easier way?
If there is an easier route, I'd be very happy to take it :)

Sorry I'm late on this. As I mentioned above, you can use MatAnisoDiffusion for general anisotropic diffusion. You can define the anisotropic diffusivity matrix using GenericFunctionRanTwoTensor or whatever class you see fit.
Perfect, im trying that now. The question about the functions knowing that they refer to temperature, is that handled magically?

Sorry, Im really struggling with this, I feel there is something missing from my understanding.
[Mesh]
  type = FileMesh
  file = '../mesh/bdu-tile.e'
[]

In the past I've used ADPiecewiseLinearInterpolationMaterial, and its clear how I pass temperature to determine the conductivity, in the case of this problem, its not clear (at least to me) how I tell the tensor it should use temperature as the x axis.

Stack frames: 19

You can see from my input that I have cfc-tile-conductivity defined, so again I think there is a gap in my understanding?
@hugary1995 any advice?

I would just create my own tensor material.
I dont think there's a way to specify a function of temperature from the input file for this. ParsedFunctions will not let you define that dependence.
I'm not sure what block is complaining about the missing material property.
I think it may be the material output that is struggling. This would be a bug. Could you please remove the outputs = all from your tensor material property and see if the error disappears

node.title: New MOOSE build on HPC - some tests failing
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I have set up a new installation of MOOSE on my university's HPC following the instructions at https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/hpc_install_moose.html. I am able to compile the tests and run them, and something like 98% of them are passing with no issue, but a subset of them are failing. The failed tests all seem to be for similar reasons (CRASH) - when I look at their outputs, many of them exit with code 11 due to segfaults in one or more of the MPI processes. I've included the full console output from the tests, but at a glance the following tests are failing for me:

In this case, 2583 of the tests passed before maximum failures was reached. Thank you for your help with this - the full console output from the tests is attached. Please let me know if any other information would help.
tests_log.txt

Hello
Someone might know what is in common between all these tests. But if not,

Do these tests pass when ran individually?
If not, could you please compile in debug mode and get us the backtrace?

Guillaume

Sorry for the extremely late reply - combination of vacation/starting an internship separate from this work. I've tried the two steps you suggested - when run individually, these tests still fail (with segfaults for the most part). However, when I compile and run in debug mode, they exit gracefully with no errors. This is strange to me, and I'm also I'm not sure how to get a useful backtrace without the error occurring again. Not sure where to go from here?

Closing this.
If debug passes and opt fails, it's likely that an old library got linked, and that it needs to be rebuilt.
make clobberall OR commit everything then git clean -xfd will take care of that (the second better than the first).

node.title: lower-dimensional meshes and VectorVariableComponentAux
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
I populate a CONSTANT MONOMIAL_VEC AuxVariable from an AuxKernel successfully.  However, zeroes are erroneously returned when i use a VectorVariableComponentAux to extract components of it when I have meshes with mixed-dimensional elements:

for 3D elements, everything is correct;
for 2D elements, the "z" component of the VectorVariableComponentAux is always zero, irrespective of the z value of the MONOMIAL_VEC, even if Mesh dimension and Spatial dimension are 3;
for 1D elements, the "y" and "z" components are zero.

I'm not sure whether this is a bug, or deliberate, or whether I have to provide a certain flag or input-file command to retrieve the correct value.
a

@rwcarlsen will know.
I m curious too
Upon first glance, this seems like a bug.  I'd need to dig more into the code to see if there are any design issues that prevent us from providing a more sensible result.
Created an issue so we dont loose track of it. This could be consequential to some people

node.title: How to load the Nemesis mesh group ?
node.bodyText:
Say I have outputs from a single calculation
out_PTOfilm_e25_T298K_E0_E0.e.N.M
where N is number of total processors and M is the processor index. I want to load the group of these files as my mesh for a new calculation (same partitioning). Is this possible?
Along with file = out_PTOfilm_e25_T298K_E0_E0.e, I tried to add nemesis=true and skip_partition= true in the [Mesh] block and that does nothing.
I also checked the test/tests/mesh/nemesis_test.i test and I have the same syntax to load the files.
The weird thing is that the error message says that it sees the files but for example,
*** ERROR ***
Error opening ExodusII mesh file: /lcrc/project/Meso/projects/ferret/out_PTOfilm_e25_T298K_E0_E46.e.256.060
thanks
John

Hi
I'm new to MOOSE, and also meet that error when I was intending to use the Exodus file generated by Trelis in Mesh block.
The chmod command may solve that error to change the ExodusII mesh file's [out_PTOfilm_e25_T298K_E0_E46.e.256.060] mode.
hope that helps you
Hu
Is this solved?

I checked with the example moose/test/tests/meshgenerators/distributed_rectilinear/dmg_displaced_mesh there, loading modifying it to load the nemesis mesh group and it worked fine.
Closing this

node.title: SideSetsFromNormalsGenerator produces speckled pattern instead of the full surface
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
I'm a relatively new user of moose and for my first non-tutorial simulation I am stuck at defining sidesets in order to define boundary conditions. I have a mesh generated with gmsh that consists of a single surface. I wanted to use the SideSetsFromNormalsGenerator to simply have a separate sideset for the x and y side. If I only output the mesh the result is the speckled pattern seen below:

My code looks like this:
[Problem]
    solve = false
[]

[Mesh]
    [roi]
        type = FileMeshGenerator
        file = 'mesh.msh'
        dim = 3
    []

    [sideSet]
        type = SideSetsFromNormalsGenerator
        input = roi
        new_boundary = 'x-side
                        y-side'
        replace = true
        normals = 
            '1 0 0
             0 1 0'
        tolerance = 1e5
        variance = 1e-1
        fixed_normal = false
    []
[]

[Outputs]
    exodus = true
[]

The goal would be to have the whole side covered. I tried playing around with the tolerance and variance parameters but without improving the result. The files I used are
sideset-problem.zip
I also tried to use the SideSetsFromPointsGenerator but that did not produce any sideset at all.
Perhaps Moose is not the right tool for the job. However, e.g. Paraview does not offer a straight-forward way to define new sidesets or something similar. If you have an idea of any different approach or a different tool I could use, or if you think this is the wrong way to go proceed I would be happy to hear other suggestions.
Thanks a lot!
Boundaries such as this are typically added with the program that created the mesh. I am not familiar with gmsh, but perhaps @lindsayad could help out.

Thanks for your comment.
Yes, I figured that there must be some other possibilities. I'm currently working with a single .stl file that encodes the full surface. In gmsh there is the possibility to assign different physical groups to geometric entities but at least in the GUI I could not find the option to split my one surface into multiple geometric entities in order to assign different names to different sections.
The tolerance you are using on the sideset generator is too big. I think you meant to use 1e-5 not 1e5
Changing the tolerance parameter was one of the first things I tried. At least visually, the values 1e5, 1, 1e-5 and 1e-10 all produce the same result.

Closing this.
I ll add a note to the sidesetfromnormalgenerator. It also does internal faces.
The right one to use here was
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/SideSetsAroundSubdomainGenerator.html
with a normals argument

node.title: Peacock crashing
node.bodyText:
Hi All,
I tried to run the peacock by run "./peacock", But it always shows an error like this "zsh: segmentation fault  ./peacock" and python quit unexpectedly like the following:
process:               python3.7 [24078]

Version:               0
Code Type:             X86-64 (Native)
Parent Process:        zsh [23344]
Responsible:           Terminal [432]
User ID:               501
How to solve this problem?

Hi,
You seem to be using the system python. Did you install moose using conda? If so you need to use the conda python.
Guillaume

Hi,
I think I installed moose using conda. I followed the installation instructions from the moose website: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html
Ethan

what does which python return?
We need peacock to use the python from conda
It returns to "/Users/chongjie/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin/python"

Ok it might be a different issue then
@aeslaughter will know more about Peacock failures on mac
Are you using BigSur? It was only recently that we have peacock working with it. @milljm did you get BigSur working?
Yes, I use BigSur.

Unfortunately, Big Sur won't work, until this PR makes it in: #17106, #17105
A work-around, would be for you to build these Conda packages yourself. If you're willing, I can walk you through it. It will require sudo rights.

Hi @milljm ,
Can you explain the necessary steps for this issue? I am having the same issue with Peacock on Bigsur.
Thank you.

I had a similar question earlier. I'll paste here what I wrote them:
cd moose
# add my remote (for the updated recipes necessary for BigSur).
git remote add jason https://github.com/milljm/moose
git fetch jason
git checkout jason/17105-python3.9
# get out of the moose environment if it's activated
conda deactivate
cond install conda-build
cd conda/mpich
conda build .
cd ../libmesh_vtk
conda build . --use-local
cd ../petsc
conda build . --use-local
cd ../libmesh
conda build . --use-local
cd ../tools
conda build .
If all goes well, you'll have all the moose-packages built locally. To install these into a new environment:
conda create -n bigsur --use-local moose-tools
conda activate bigsur
conda install --use-local moose-libmesh
Hopefully that works! Once installed, you can safely move back to using moose/master head.

Thank you.

node.title: Tutorial 2: MultiApps has an invalid link
node.bodyText:
The page (https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/getting_started/examples_and_tutorials/tutorial02_multiapps/index.html) has an invalid link: https://mooseframework.org/getting_started/examples_and_tutorials/tutorial02_multiapps/slides
The page (https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Transfers/index.html) has an invalid link to the MultiApps: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/MultiApps/index.md. I think the correct link is: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/MultiApps/index.html

Thank you for reporting this!
There's a PR up for the website to fix the first point momentarily.
In the mean time, you can build this documentation locally with
cd tutorials/tutorial02_multiapps/doc
python moosedocs.py build --serve

I ll make a PR to address the second point.
